typical_vesting_schedule: 4-year vesting with a 1-year cliff, then monthly vesting
risk_flags: No severance clause (implies no guaranteed payout if terminated)
Overly broad non-compete (especially problematic in states that ban them)
Clawback provisions on bonuses or equity (e.g. requiring pay-back if leaving)
Extensive IP claim on personal projects done off-work
negotiation_tips: Benchmark your salary (use tools like Levels.fyi or Glassdoor) and be prepared to negotiate on total compensation. Highlight your specialized skills or accomplishments to justify a higher equity grant or signing bonus. If the base salary offered is at the top of the band, consider asking for additional stock or a one-time bonus. Ensure any promised bonus or stock refresh is written into the offer.

standard_clauses: Non-compete / Non-solicit clauses (may be limited by jurisdiction)
Potential severance clause (often negotiable for senior roles)
risk_flags: No severance provision for termination without cause
Non-compete that limits working for competitors for an excessive period
Ambiguous bonus/commission structure or employer ability to change it unilaterally
Lack of 'double-trigger' acceleration (if equity is important and company is acquired)
negotiation_tips: Demonstrate your impact (e.g., projects led, systems designed) to justify top-of-band pay. Negotiate not just base salary but also equity refreshers or a higher bonus target – senior roles often have flexibility in these areas. If you have competing offers or know market rates, use that data to back your requests. Also consider negotiating severance or role-specific perks (like dedicated training budget or conference attendance) given your seniority.

standard_clauses: Non-compete clause (scope often limited to direct competitors for 6-12 months)
No guaranteed severance (termination handled per company policy)
risk_flags: No equity or bonus mentioned (could signal below-market offer)
Overbroad non-compete restricting future PM roles in the industry
Unclear IP ownership (ensure personal side projects are excluded)
Missing severance or termination protections (common at this level, but worth noting)
negotiation_tips: Highlight your successful product launches or key metrics you've driven when negotiating – this evidence can justify a higher salary or equity grant. If the base salary is at the lower end, consider asking for a larger equity grant or a sign-on bonus. Clarify how performance bonuses are determined; if none exist, you might negotiate for one tied to product outcomes. Also, ensure your job level aligns with your experience – you can negotiate a title upgrade (e.g., to Senior PM) if your experience warrants, which brings a higher pay band.

standard_clauses: Strict NDA and IP assignment (handling sensitive product strategy)
Non-compete clause (tailored to product/industry, often 6-12 months if included)
At-will employment, with possible severance terms for involuntary separation
Non-solicitation (cannot poach team or clients post-employment)
Invention disclosure requirements (must report product ideas related to company)
typical_vesting_schedule: 4 years total (25% at 1-year, then monthly vesting)
risk_flags: Equity grant absent or very low (below market for senior role)
Non-compete that broadly prevents working in any similar industry for long period
No definition of bonus criteria (or fully discretionary bonus with no guidelines)
No severance for a high-level role (consider negotiating one)
No vesting acceleration on change of control (could lose unvested equity if company sold)
negotiation_tips: Use data on senior PM compensation (e.g., from salary surveys) to justify your ask at the higher end of the range. Emphasize your leadership impact — for instance, cite revenue or user growth from products you've managed — to argue for more equity or a higher bonus percentage. You can negotiate for a better title (like 'Director of Product' or similar) if the scope is large, which often comes with a pay bump. Also consider negotiating an agreement on severance or accelerated vesting (double-trigger) given the seniority, and ensure any verbal promises (like team expansion, budget commitments) are added to the offer letter.
